Caption: Figure 12: The percentage change in MTTR and MTTF when the WS trace is split at one-and-half months.
Mention:
were small, we could indeed predict TTF (or TTR) based on the historical MTTF (or MTTR). Figure 9 plots
the coefficient of variance (defined as the ratio of standard deviation to mean) of TTR and TTF in PL trace.
Most nodes have a coefficient greater than 1.0 which implies quite a wide probability distribution. Similar
results hold for WS trace as shown in Figure 10. Again, we do not analyze DNS trace for previously
mentioned reasons.
Given that TTR and TTF cannot be accurately predicted, we turn to the predictability of MTTF and
MTTR. We split the traces into two parts and for each node compare the MTTR and MTTF observed in
one part with the other. Figure 11 plots the percentage difference in MTTR and MTTF between the first 8
months and the remaining 9 months of PL trace. Clearly, the MTTR and MTTF for most nodes do not vary
significantly over the two periods. We observe similar results for other splits of the PL trace (Figure 13)
We also observe similar results for WS trace (Figure 12). We do not perform this study for DNS trace
because of its short duration.
